fields.descriptive_line: Balarama, Bronze, Bihar, Eastern India, c. 958AD or 964AD
fields.physical_description: A four-armed deity stands on  a single inverted lotus pedestal with right leg stiffly planted and the left leg, slightly forward, is bent at the knee in an expression of ease. His lower garment is  with a girdle at the waist and pleated at the centre. Besides a scarf is tied to the garment above the thighs.  There is a five-hooded snake canopy behind the head of the deity signifying his association with the primordial snake Sesa or Ananta.  He wears various ornaments, such as a crown (kirita), necklaces, bangles, armlets, a sacred thread (upavita) and a long garland of flowers (vanamala) like that of Vasudeva-Krsna or Visnu.  In his two front hands he holds a sankha (right) and a cakra (left).  This as an earlier stage of the sculptural development, that is why his back hands are still lowered down and shown holding a psetle (musala) and a ploughshare (hala), no doubt showing his connection with agriculture. The pitha (pedestal) is plain rectangle with two vertical columns over which is placed  a cross-bar.  Behind his head is given a halo(sirascakra) with a design of flame and having a jewel (mani) at the apex.on the cross-bar comprises of a five-hooded snake canopy encircled by a thick border of flame tips with a mani (jewel) at the apex.  Below at the right corner of the pedestal a tiny figure is shown, perhaps the donor of the image, holding a garland.
fields.dimensions: Height: 27 cm, Width: 11.3 cm, Depth: 7.7 cm
fields.title: Balarama

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.marks:
Gorakshkar had read and translated the incription in the following way:

sri rajyapala deva rajye samvat 37 sri rahagrha
visaye bhata jivala grama vastavya ta (ma...maksa)
suta devadharmmaya balabhadra (murti) pratipaditasyah /  "Records the gift of an image of Balabhadra by a donor (name not clear) who was a resident of bhata Jivala Grama, in the Rajgriha cishaya. in the 37th regnal year of Rajyapala."  See S.Gorakshkar, Some Inscripbed Balarama Images from Eastern India, Lalit Kala, No.19, 1979, p.29.
fields.bibliography:
Gorakshwar, Chowdhury, 1967, p59, R.Skelton ( ed.) Skelton, R., and Francis, M., (eds). ‘Arts of Bengal : the heritage of Bangladesh and eastern India’. London : Whitechapel Art Gallery, [1979]. ISBN 085488047X. S
Huntington, Susan L. The "Pala-Sena” Schools of Sculpture. Leiden : E.J. Brill, 1984, fig. 48.
Sadashiv Gorakshkar. 'Some Inscribed Balarama Images from Eastern India' in Lalit Kala, 19, New Delhi 1979, Plate XLIV and pp. 27-32.
fields.history_note: Purchased from Spink and Son Limited  for £1600
fields.historical_context_note: Balarama probably has his origins as an incarnation (avatara) of Visnu, although usually worshipped in association with his half-brother Krishna. He holds attributes associated with agriculture, including a plough (hala) and a pestle (musala).  An insctiption cast on the reverse of this image records that it was a gift of a resident of Rajagriha (Rajgir) district in the 37th year of the reign of the Pala king Rajyapala, equivalent to c. 957 A.D or, according to recent scholarship, 964 A.D.
